title: Aaron Paul says it was 'nice to be with' Breaking Bad's Jessie Pinkman again in El Camino
text:
He played Jesse Pinkman, the not-so brilliant sidekick to Bryan Cranston's Walter White, for more than five years on the hugely successful hit AMC series Breaking Bad.

Now, some six years on from the series finale, and Aaron Paul is back in the driver's seat for the follow-up Netflix film, El Camino: A Breaking Bad Movie.

And despite coming to terms with the end of the series, and his much-loved character, Paul relished the chance to take on the role again from the moment he got word that series creator-writer Vince Gilligan was interested in doing a movie.

Monumental: Aaron Paul said it was 'a dream come true' to revisit his character Jesse Pinkman in El Camino: A Breaking Bad Movie

'It was a dream come true,' Paul said of his return as Jesse Pinkman, while on the red carpet of the film's premiere in Los Angeles on Monday, in a video posted by Independent.

'I thought I had said goodbye to this guy so long ago [2013].

He added, 'I thought I said goodbye to so many of those crew members, at least as a business relationship. It was so nice to revisit with them and reconnect with them and also zip on this skin once again.'

Familiar feeling: Feeling nostalgic Paul said, 'I miss this guy, you know. It was nice to be with him again,' during an interview at the film's premiere in Los Angeles on Monday

Paul was feeling more than just a little nostalgic when he described his time back in the shoes of the character that sent his acting career soaring after the series premiere in January 2008.

'I miss this guy, you know. It was nice to be with him again,' he said.

For the premiere, Paul reunited with many of his Breaking Bad co-stars that included Bryan Cranston (Walter White), Dean Norris (Hank Schrader), Jesse Plemons (Todd Alquist) , Kristen Ritter (Jane Margolis), Giancarlo Espositi (Gustavo Fring), Betsy Brandt (Marie Schrader) Jonathan Banks (Mike Ehrmantraut), Charles Baker (Skinny Pete) and Matt L. Jones (Badger).

It is still not known which of the original characters from the series will re-emerging in the film.

Making a statement: Paul made his grand arrival at the premiere in an El Camino with police officers hot on his trail, which was an ode to story-line of the much-anticipated follow-up film

Reunited! Many of Paul's Breaking Bad co-stars were on hand for the film premiere; pictured are creator-writer Vince Gilligan, Charles Baker (Skinny Pete), Krysten Ritter (Jane Margolis), Matt L. Jones (Badger), Betsy Brandt (Marie Schrader), Paul, Dean Norris (Hank Schrader), Jonathan Banks (Mike Ehrmantraut) , Giancarlo Esposito (Gus Fring), Bryan Cranston (Walter White), and Jesse Plemons (Todd Alquist)

Paul, 40, made his grand arrival at the Monday premiere in a black El Camino with police officers hot on his trail, which was an ode to story-line of the much-anticipated follow-up film.

When we last saw Pinkman in the Breaking Bad series finale, he was speeding off in a hysterical frenzy in that El Camino after Walter White (Bryan Cranstan) saved him from his captors who had enslaved him to produce mass amounts of methamphetamine.

After White rigged a remote-control machine that wiped out the captors, the two partners in crime stared at each other in a tense standoff that resulted in Pinkman refusing White's request for him to kill him.

The eventually parted ways with one last nod of respect to one another.

Mystery: It's still not know if Cranston's Walter White will appear in the new film

Back for more: El Camino: A Breaking Bad Movie premieres on Netflix October 11; Paul is pictured with creator-writer Vince Gilligan

Breaking Bad, the series, ran from 2008 to 2013 and garnered widespread acclaim from both fans and critics around the world.

It followed White, a terminally ill high school chemistry teacher as he created a meth empire with Pinkman, his former inept student.

El Camino: A Breaking Bad Movie premieres on Netflix October 11.
description: He played Jesse Pinkman, the not-so brilliant sidekick to Bryan Cranston's Walter White, for more than five years on the hugely successful hit AMC series Breaking Bad.
